Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: GENETICS OF LIFE CYCLE EVOLUTION AND THE EFFECTS ON TEMPORAL ISOLATION AND GENE FLOW
Award.AbstractNarration:
The long-term goal of the research is to understand the process of speciation, in which one species splits into two, often through the evolution of multiple forms of reproductive isolation. The project focuses on reproductive isolation that occurs because of differences in the timing of major life cycle events, a widespread and potentially major impetus for speciation when differences in time of reproduction restrict gene flow. In a multi-pronged approach that applies high-throughput DNA sequencing, genetic mapping, population genomic analysis, metabolic profiling and field experiments the research will examine the genetic basis of life cycle variation and temporal reproductive isolation in the European corn borer moth (Ostrinia nubilalis), and evaluate the consequence of these differences in preventing gene flow between populations in nature. These experiments will provide a rare glimpse into the role of temporal isolation in origin of new species.

Although a superb model for speciation, the European corn borer is also a major pest of corn and other crops, costing the United States ~$1B each year. By leveraging the moth as an organism of both scientific and economic interest, the research builds community partnerships to simultaneously promote basic scientific discovery, public understanding of the relevance of evolution in daily life, and sustainable agriculture.

POR.DRECONTENT:
European corn borer (ECB) moths were accidentally brought to North America by people and, as with other biological systems interfered with by humans, the ECB in North America is providing may interesting evolutionary insights. Female ECB moths attract males using scents (pheromones) and there are two forms of ECB, one which produces an E pheromone and one which produces a Z pheromone. These pheromones are chemically different and ‘smell’ different to the moths. There are genetic differences between E moths and Z moths, including a major difference in their sex chromosomes. However, E and Z moths can interbreed (hybridize) and therefore can exchange genes so should be considered different forms within the same species rather than different species. As well as the pheromone variation in ECB moths, there is also variation in how many generations per year a particular form of moth may go through. This adds to the complexity, because you can have one type of Z moth with one generation per year, and another type with two generations per year. While E and Z moths producing the same number of generations per year living in the same place may hybridize, because adults of the two forms will be flying at the same time, a two-generation per year E moth will not readily hybridize with a one-generation per year Z moth.

 

This complexity sets up fascinating patterns of variation geographically, particularly with numbers of generations, because, not surprisingly it is easier to have more generations in more southerly areas. We have shown that there are genetic markers that track this life history variation. What is most extraordinary have been our findings of exchange of genes between E and Z moths in the same location. We can show genetically that there is little hybridization between the E and Z moths in the same locality if they have a different number of generations – as expected. Where the E and Z moths in the same locality have the same number of generations, then hybridization, and genetic exchange, can occur. However, this is where the difference in the sex chromosomes between E and Z moths becomes important. There is a sex chromosome region where genes are in an inverted order in E moths compared with what you find in Z moths, and for that DNA region E and Z moths do not exchange genes. The E and Z moths can potentially remain or become genetically very different from each other, just in that region. These results are a fascinating insight into the origin of new species. They show how differences in time of breeding can drive genetic isolation. The results also show how forms that can interbreed are still potentially able to become species because of regions of their DNA that are ‘protected’ from exchange and so can potentially promote enough differences for new species to form. Such mechanisms of species formation have been found in other organisms, but the ECB moths are an exciting system to study because we know enough about their genetics and life history to have a detailed picture of the processes that lead to differentiation and ultimately to new species. For instance, the genetic basis of the pheromone types and the generation times and the characterization of the inverted sex chromosome region that inhibits genetic exchange. Our studies have contributed substantially to this mass of genetic information with, for instance, 116 individual ECB moths with a full sequence of their DNA newly analyzed. To have data on these numbers of individuals is important because of complexity of different forms and geographical variation, which we have captured in the range of individuals that we have characterized.
